metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: With the subplot() function you can draw multiple plots in one figure:
content.html: With the subplot() function you can draw multiple plots in one figure:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as np#plot 1:x = 
  np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
  plt.plot(x,y)#plot 2:x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 
  40])plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as np#plot 1:x =
np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
plt.plot(x,y)#plot 2:x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30,
40])plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as np#plot 1:x = 
  np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
  plt.plot(x,y)#plot 2:x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 
 40])plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

#plot 1:
x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
plt.plot(x,y)

#plot 2:
x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40])

plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)
plt.plot(x,y)

plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as np#plot 1:x = 
  np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
  plt.plot(x,y)#plot 2:x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 
  40])plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.show()

content.text: The subplot() function takes three arguments that describes the layout of the figure.
content.html: The subplot() function takes three arguments that describes the layout of the figure.

content.text: The layout is organized in rows and columns, which are represented by the first and second argument.
content.html: The layout is organized in rows and columns, which are represented by the first and second argument.

content.text: The third argument represents the index of the current plot.
content.html: The third argument represents the index of the current plot.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
#the figure has 1 row, 2 columns, and this plot is the first plot.
#the figure has 1 row, 2 columns, and this plot is the first plot.

content.text: So, if we want a figure with 2 rows an 1 column (meaning that the two plots will be displayed on top of each other instead of side-by-side), we can write the syntax like this:
content.html: So, if we want a figure with 2 rows an 1 column (meaning that the two plots will be displayed on top of each other instead of side-by-side), we can write the syntax like this:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as np#plot 1:x = 
  np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(2, 1, 1)
  plt.plot(x,y)#plot 2:x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 
  40])plt.subplot(2, 1, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.show()

plt.plot(x,y)#plot 2:x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30,
40])plt.subplot(2, 1, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.show()

import numpy as np

y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.subplot(2, 1, 1)
plt.plot(x,y)

#plot 2:
x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40])

plt.subplot(2, 1, 2)
plt.plot(x,y)

plt.show()

content.text: You can draw as many plots you like on one figure, just descibe the number of rows, columns, and the index of the plot.
content.html: You can draw as many plots you like on one figure, just descibe the number of rows, columns, and the index of the plot.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as npx = np.array([0, 
  1, 2, 3])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(2, 3, 1)
  plt.plot(x,y)x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 
  40])plt.subplot(2, 3, 2)plt.plot(x,y)x = np.array([0, 1, 
  2, 3])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(2, 3, 3)plt.plot(x,y)
  x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40])
  plt.subplot(2, 3, 4)plt.plot(x,y)x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = 
  np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(2, 3, 5)plt.plot(x,y)x 
  = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40])plt.subplot(2, 
  3, 6)plt.plot(x,y)plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.subplot(2, 3, 1)
plt.plot(x,y)

x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40])

plt.subplot(2, 3, 2)
plt.plot(x,y)

x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.subplot(2, 3, 3)
plt.plot(x,y)

x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40])

plt.subplot(2, 3, 4)
plt.plot(x,y)

x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.subplot(2, 3, 5)
plt.plot(x,y)

x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40])

plt.subplot(2, 3, 6)
plt.plot(x,y)

plt.show()

content.text: You can add a title to each plot with the title() function:
content.html: You can add a title to each plot with the title() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as np#plot 1:x = 
  np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
  plt.plot(x,y)plt.title("SALES")#plot 2:x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 
  40])plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.title("INCOME")
  plt.show()

plt.plot(x,y)plt.title("SALES")#plot 2:x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30,
40])plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.title("INCOME")
plt.show()

 plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

#plot 1:
x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
plt.plot(x,y)
plt.title("SALES")

#plot 2:
x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40])

plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)
plt.plot(x,y)
plt.title("INCOME")

plt.show()

  np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
  plt.plot(x,y)plt.title("SALES")#plot 2:x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 
  40])plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.title("INCOME")
  plt.show()

content.text: You can add a title to the entire figure with the suptitle() function:
content.html: You can add a title to the entire figure with the suptitle() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltimport numpy as np#plot 1:x = 
  np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
  plt.plot(x,y)plt.title("SALES")#plot 2:x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 
  40])plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.title("INCOME")
  plt.suptitle("MY SHOP")plt.show()

40])plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)plt.plot(x,y)plt.title("INCOME")
plt.suptitle("MY SHOP")plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

#plot 1:
x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
plt.plot(x,y)
plt.title("SALES")

#plot 2:
x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
y = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40])

plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)
plt.plot(x,y)
plt.title("INCOME")

plt.suptitle("MY SHOP")
plt.show()
